comments:
AFter successfully using TPTP for profiling a Java application I tried to test a Web Application. Recording of a test was easy and intuitive. But when I try to start the test I just get a error message dialog

Resource /data is not open.

What does it mean? When I look into eclipse log I get this:

!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.resources 4 372 2005-12-23 15:49:25.278
!MESSAGE Resource /data is not open.
Scott, please take a look at this.  Not sure if it may be Windows 2000 specific or not.  I've tentatively targeted it to 4.2 (without knowing whether it really deserves that or not).
I guess it has something to do with the project where the resource is stored in. Perhaps this project needs a specific state that wasn't available when TPTP was trying to run it (closed project?).
Yes, the project needs to be in an open state for TPTP to access it -- is this the case, does it work once you manually opened the project?
Yes, the project needs to be in an open state for TPTP to access it -- is this the case, does it work once you manually opened the project?

So, the result is, that the project wasn't open. The message "Resource ... is not open." is missleading, for this reason. Better stay with the term "Project" as it is a project and everybody knows what is missing.
Okay, got it -- so the issue is to fix the exception/UI handling of this condition.  I will re-assign to the UI folks, thanks.

If I correctly understand the problem, you have tried to run a test and because the project containing the test was closed you recieved this confusing exception.

How can I reproduce this ? When the project is closed the test is no longer accessible, so I can start it ...

Well, I just started with TPTP and created a new test project ("PerfTest"). But As I tested performances of some other existing projects, I also saved the performance files in the corresponding other projects folder. And this other project was closed.

The message "Resource/data is not open" is sent by the eclipse platform to inform the user that he tries to access a not accessible resource. This can be either a closed project or a file (or a folder) located inside a closed project, this is the reason why the generic term of "resource" is used in the message.
 
In TPTP, we just catch the exception and log it with its original message.
If you think this message is not understandable or not sufficient, you would rather fill a defect to the platform.core resource component which is the originator of the message.

Closing by default since not closed by the originator in the 7+ months since being resolved.  

Please reopen if the issue is still present in the latest TPTP release or the resolution is not correct.
